title: CVPR_2010_30_abs

sentences.text: We introduce a method to accelerate the evaluation of object detection cascades with the help of a divide-and-conquer procedure in the space of candidate regions .

Compared to the exhaustive procedure that thus far is the state-of-the-art for cascade evaluation , the proposed method requires fewer evaluations of the classifier functions , thereby speeding up the search .
Furthermore , we show how the recently developed efficient subwindow search -LRB- ESS -RRB- procedure -LSB- 11 -RSB- can be integrated into the last stage of our method .

This allows us to use our method to act not only as a faster procedure for cascade evaluation , but also as a tool to perform efficient branch-and-bound object detection with nonlinear quality functions , in particular kernel-ized support vector machines .
Experiments on the PASCAL VOC 2006 dataset show an acceleration of more than 50 % by our method compared to standard cascade evaluation .

Entity-our_method.label: our method
Entity-our_method.description: Our method refers to a novel approach for accelerating the evaluation of object detection cascades through a divide-and-conquer strategy, which integrates efficient subwindow search techniques to enhance performance in branch-and-bound object detection using kernelized support vector machines.

Entity-branch-and-bound_object_detection.label: branch-and-bound object detection
Entity-branch-and-bound_object_detection.description: Branch-and-bound object detection is an efficient method for evaluating object detection cascades that utilizes a divide-and-conquer strategy to minimize the number of classifier evaluations, particularly when applied with nonlinear quality functions such as kernelized support vector machines.

Entity-method.label: method
Entity-method.description: The method refers to a novel approach for accelerating the evaluation of object detection cascades using a divide-and-conquer strategy to reduce the number of classifier function evaluations.

Entity-last_stage.label: last stage
aliases: the last stage of our method
Entity-last_stage.description: The 'last stage' refers to the final phase of the proposed method for accelerating object detection cascade evaluation, where the efficient subwindow search (ESS) procedure is integrated to enhance performance.

mentions.local_name: the last stage of our method

Entity-acceleration_of_more_than_50_.label: acceleration of more than 50 %
Entity-acceleration_of_more_than_50_.description: The mention 'acceleration of more than 50 %' refers to the improvement in the speed of object detection cascade evaluation achieved by the proposed method in the experiments conducted on the PASCAL VOC 2006 dataset.

Entity-tool.label: tool
Entity-tool.description: The 'tool' refers to a method developed for accelerating the evaluation of object detection cascades, enabling efficient branch-and-bound object detection using nonlinear quality functions, particularly with kernelized support vector machines.

Entity-search.label: search
Entity-search.description: The term 'search' refers to the process of evaluating candidate regions in object detection cascades, which is accelerated by the proposed method that reduces the number of classifier function evaluations compared to traditional exhaustive procedures.

Entity-efficient_subwindow_search.label: efficient subwindow search
Entity-efficient_subwindow_search.description: Efficient subwindow search (ESS) is a recently developed search technique that optimizes the process of locating candidate regions in object detection tasks, allowing for faster evaluations and integration into advanced detection methods.

Entity-cascade_evaluation.label: cascade evaluation
Entity-cascade_evaluation.description: Cascade evaluation refers to a method used in object detection that involves a series of classifiers arranged in a cascade structure, where each classifier is responsible for filtering out negative samples, thereby improving the efficiency of the detection process.

Entity-object_detection_cascade.label: object detection cascades
Entity-object_detection_cascade.description: Object detection cascades are a series of sequential algorithms or models used in computer vision to progressively refine and improve the accuracy of detecting objects within images.

Entity-exhaustive_procedure.label: exhaustive procedure
Entity-exhaustive_procedure.description: The 'exhaustive procedure' refers to the current state-of-the-art method for evaluating object detection cascades, which involves a comprehensive search through candidate regions to optimize classifier function evaluations.

Entity-candidate_region.label: candidate regions
Entity-candidate_region.description: Candidate regions refer to specific areas in an image that are proposed for potential object detection, which are evaluated using a divide-and-conquer method to improve the efficiency of object detection cascades.

Entity-standard_cascade_evaluation.label: standard cascade evaluation
Entity-standard_cascade_evaluation.description: Standard cascade evaluation refers to the traditional method used for assessing the performance of object detection cascades, which involves exhaustive evaluations of classifier functions to determine detection accuracy.

Entity-pascal_voc_2006.label: PASCAL VOC 2006
Entity-pascal_voc_2006.description: PASCAL VOC 2006 is a benchmark dataset used for evaluating object detection and image segmentation algorithms, consisting of annotated images and associated challenges.

Entity-divide-and-conquer_procedure.label: divide-and-conquer procedure
Entity-divide-and-conquer_procedure.description: A divide-and-conquer procedure is an algorithmic strategy that solves a problem by recursively breaking it down into smaller subproblems, solving each subproblem independently, and then combining their solutions to form a solution to the original problem.

Entity-kernel-ized_support_vector_machin.label: kernel-ized support vector machines
Entity-kernel-ized_support_vector_machin.description: Kernel-ized support vector machines are a type of machine learning algorithm that utilize kernel functions to enable linear separation in high-dimensional feature spaces, enhancing the performance of traditional support vector machines.

Entity-nonlinear_quality_function.label: nonlinear quality functions
Entity-nonlinear_quality_function.description: Nonlinear quality functions refer to mathematical functions used to evaluate the performance of object detection algorithms, particularly in the context of kernelized support vector machines, enabling efficient branch-and-bound search methods.

Entity-classifier_function.label: classifier functions
Entity-classifier_function.description: Classifier functions refer to the mathematical functions used in machine learning models, particularly in the context of object detection, to classify candidate regions based on their features.

Entity-state-of-the-art.label: state-of-the-art
Entity-state-of-the-art.description: state-of-the-art refers to the highest level of development or performance achieved in a particular field or technology, often representing the best practices or methods currently available.

summary: We introduce a method to accelerate the evaluation of object detection cascades with the help of a divide-and-conquer procedure in the space of candidate regions . Compared to the exhaustive procedure that thus far is the state-of-the-art for cascade evaluation , the proposed method requires fewer evaluations of the classifier functions , thereby speeding up the search . Furthermore , we show how the recently developed efficient subwindow search -LRB- ESS -RRB- procedure -LSB- 11 -RSB- can be integrated into the last stage of our method . This allows us to use our method to act not only as a faster procedure for cascade evaluation , but also as a tool to perform efficient branch-and-bound object detection with nonlinear quality functions , in particular kernel-ized support vector machines . Experiments on the PASCAL VOC 2006 dataset show an acceleration of more than 50 % by our method compared to standard cascade evaluation .

Predicate-accelerates_the_evaluation_of.label: accelerates the evaluation of
Predicate-accelerates_the_evaluation_of.description: The predicate 'accelerates the evaluation of' indicates that the subject facilitates or speeds up the process of assessing or analyzing the object. In this context, the subject is a method or approach that enhances the efficiency or effectiveness of evaluating the object, which can be any system, process, or entity that requires assessment.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates that the subject employs or utilizes the object as a means to achieve a specific purpose or outcome. It establishes a functional relationship where the subject actively engages with the object to perform a task, implement a strategy, or apply a technique.

Predicate-operates_in_the_space_of.label: operates in the space of
Predicate-operates_in_the_space_of.description: The predicate 'operates in the space of' indicates that the subject is functioning or being applied within a specific domain, context, or set of parameters represented by the object. It suggests that the subject's processes, actions, or methodologies are relevant to, or interact with, the characteristics or elements defined by the object.

Predicate-speeds_up.label: speeds up
Predicate-speeds_up.description: The predicate 'speeds up' indicates an action or process by which the subject enhances the efficiency or quickness of the object. It implies that the subject contributes to a reduction in the time required for the object to be completed or achieved, thereby facilitating a faster outcome.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' serves as a linking verb that establishes an identity or equivalence between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject can be defined or categorized by the object, suggesting that they share a fundamental relationship or characteristic. In this context, the subject is being described or classified by the object, implying that the object represents a defining quality or type of the subject.

Predicate-compared_to.label: compared to
Predicate-compared_to.description: The predicate 'compared to' establishes a relationship of evaluation or contrast between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is being assessed in relation to the object. This comparison may highlight similarities, differences, advantages, or disadvantages, providing a basis for understanding the characteristics or effectiveness of the subject in the context of the object.

Predicate-can_be_integrated_into.label: can be integrated into
Predicate-can_be_integrated_into.description: The predicate 'can be integrated into' indicates a potential relationship where the subject has the capability or suitability to be incorporated or combined with the object, suggesting that the subject can function effectively within the context or framework provided by the object.

Predicate-are_used_in.label: are used in
Predicate-are_used_in.description: The predicate 'are used in' indicates a functional relationship where the subject represents a method, technique, or tool that is applied or implemented within the context of the object, which typically denotes a specific application, field, or process. This connection highlights the practical utility of the subject in achieving objectives or solving problems related to the object.

Predicate-shows.label: shows
Predicate-shows.description: The predicate 'shows' indicates a relationship where the subject presents, demonstrates, or reveals information, characteristics, or results related to the object. It implies that the subject provides evidence or an illustration of the object, allowing for an understanding or interpretation of the object's significance or properties.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the object represents a more general or inclusive category that encompasses the subject. This relationship suggests that the subject is a specific instance or type within the broader category defined by the object.
